steps.title: Eat raw garlic to decrease the number of platelets in your blood.
steps.content: Eat raw garlic to decrease the number of platelets in your blood. Raw or crushed garlic contains a compound called "allicin" which affects the body's ability to make platelets, therefore decreasing the number of platelets in the blood. [2] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Family Physicians Organization devoted to improving the health of patients, families, and communities Go to source Your body responds to the lower platelet level by improving its immunity, which helps to protect the body from any foreign objects (such as viruses and bacteria) that enter the system. The allicin content of garlic decreases rapidly with cooking, so try to eat it raw. Eating raw garlic causes stomach upset in some people, so be sure to eat the raw garlic with food.

steps.title: Take gingko biloba to reduce blood viscosity.
steps.content: Take gingko biloba to reduce blood viscosity. Gingko biloba contains substances called “terpenoids” which reduce blood viscosity (making it thinner) and prevent the formation of clots. [3] X Trustworthy Source U.S. National Capital Poison Center Independent poison control center providing resources to prevent poisonings and save lives Go to source Gingko biloba also help to improve blood circulation and increases your body's production of warfarin, which helps to dissolve clots. Gingko biloba is available as a supplement in liquid or capsule form. You can buy these supplements at the drug or health food store. If you can get your hands on gingko biloba leave, you can boil the leaves in water for 5 to 7 minutes, then drink the water as a tea.

steps.title: Use ginseng to prevent clot formation.
steps.content: Use ginseng to prevent clot formation. Ginseng contains “ginsenosides” that help to decrease platelet aggregation, and therefore prevent the formation of clots. [4] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Ginseng is available in capsule form at drug and health food stores. It is often added to energy foods and drinks. Ginseng causes insomnia and nausea in some people, so you will need to test it out for a trial period to see how it reacts with your body.

steps.title: Eat pomegranates for their anti-platelet effect.
steps.content: Eat pomegranates for their anti-platelet effect. Pomegranates contain substances called polyphenols which have an anti-platelet effect — this means that they reduce your body's production of platelets and prevent existing platelets from clotting. [5] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source You can eat whole, fresh pomegranate fruits, drink pomegranate juice, or add pomegranate extract to your cooking.

steps.title: Eat seafood rich in omega-3 to inhibit platelet production.
steps.content: Eat seafood rich in omega-3 to inhibit platelet production. Omega-3 fatty acids affect platelet activity, thinning the blood and reducing the chance of clotting. [6] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Omega-3's are abundant in seafood such as tuna, salmon, scallops, sardine, shellfish and herring. [7] X Trustworthy Source American Heart Association Leading nonprofit that funds medical research and public education Go to source Try to include 2 to 3 servings of these fish per week, to meet your recommended weekly allowance of omega-3s If you're not fond of fish, you can boost your omega-3 intake by taking 3000 to 4000mg of fish oil supplements per day.

steps.title: Drink red wine
steps.content: Drink red wine to reduce the chances of clot formation. Red wine contains flavonoids, which comes from the skin of red grapes during production. These flavonoids prevent the overproduction of cells in the lining of artery walls (a process caused by too many platelets in the blood). This reduces reduces the chances of clot formation. [8] X Trustworthy Source Science Direct Online archive of peer-reviewed research on scientific, technical and medical topics Go to source There is one unit of alcohol in half a standard glass of wine (about 175 ml). Men should not drink more than 21 units of alcohol per week, and no more than four per day. Women should not drink more than 14 units of alcohol per week, and no more than three per day. Both men and women should have at least two alcohol free days per week. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Eat fruit and veg containing "salicylates" which help to thin the blood.
steps.content: Eat fruit and veg containing "salicylates" which help to thin the blood. Fruit and vegetables that contain “salicylates” help to thin the blood and prevent clotting. They also boost the body’s immunity and help to maintain normal platelet count. [10] X Research source Vegetables that contain salicylates include cucumber, mushrooms, zucchini, radish, and alfalfa. Fruits that contain salicylates include all kinds of berries, cherries, raisins and oranges. Eating shiitake mushrooms is a good natural option for decreasing platelets.

steps.title: Add cinnamon to cooking to reduce platelet aggregation.
steps.content: Add cinnamon to cooking to reduce platelet aggregation. Cinnamon contains a compound called “cinnamaldehyde” which is known to reduce platelet aggregation and therefore blood clotting. [11] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Add ground cinnamon to baked goods or stewed vegetables. You could also try boiling a cinnamon stick in tea or wine.

steps.title: Quit smoking to prevent blood clots.
steps.content: Quit smoking to prevent blood clots. Smoking puts you at increased risk of developing blood clots, due to several harmful compounds found in cigarettes (such as nicotine). Smoking causes the blood to become thicker and the platelets to clump together. [12] X Trustworthy Source American Lung Association Nonprofit health organization dedicated to improving lung health through education, advocacy, and research Go to source Serious health issues such as heart problems and strokes often occur as a result of clots forming in the blood. Quitting smoking is one of the best things you can do to avoid these blood clots from forming in the first place. Quitting is difficult, and is not something that can be done overnight. See this article for some helpful advice on how to quit smoking.

steps.title: Drink coffee for its anti-platelet effect.
steps.content: Drink coffee for its anti-platelet effect. Coffee contains an anti-platelet effect, which means that it reduces the number of platelets in the blood and prevents platelet aggregation. [13] X Research source The anti-platelet effect of coffee is not due to caffeine, but to phenolic acids. Therefore, you can still benefit from the anti-platelet effect by drinking decaffeinated coffee. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Take blood thinning medication, as prescribed by your doctor.
steps.content: Take blood thinning medication, as prescribed by your doctor. Under certain circumstances, your doctor will prescribe blood thinning medications. These medications will prevent blood viscosity, platelet aggregation, and the formation of blood clots. Some of the most commonly prescribed medications include: [15] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Aspirin Hydroxyurea Anagrelide Interferon alfa Busulfan Pipobroman Phosphorus – 32

steps.title: Undergo a procedure known as plateletpheresis.
steps.content: Undergo a procedure known as plateletpheresis. In emergency circumstances, your doctor may advise a treatment known as plateletpheresis, which rapidly decreases the number of platelets in the blood. [16] X Research source During plateletpheresis, an intravenous line is inserted into one of your blood vessels to remove blood from your body. This blood is then passed through a machine that removes platelets from the blood. The platelet-free blood is then passed back into the body through a second intravenous line.
